Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Unmuzzled Ox - Sunburned with Paul Flaherty
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
'I f....n' love Sunburned Hand Of The Man, and this is one justifies my appreciation of their music. I'm not (yet) very familiar with Paul Flaherty, but I barely hear anything else but the boys from Massachusetts here. Side One is one of the most FUCKED UP things I've ever heard the band come up with... EVER!!!. Seriously, this one even rivals with my love of The Secret In Disguise it's so fucking out of this world! F'd up electronics, the gang-banging of a saxophone, funky lo-fi beats and an almost zealous worshipping of a vocabulary enhancer (I love the letter "B" so fucking much man!!) all adds up to some of the most mind-blowing music I've heard from the group in ages! Side Two, although it is mellower, remains as brain-dissolving as the first. Flaherty takes on a bigger role here, but there's enough of the Sunburned touch to let you know who's boss. Flipped vocals, backwards music samples? Yeah! We've got another winner here!'
Sunburned Hand of the Man.credits:
released March 1, 2010
Unmuzzled Ox - Ecstatic Peace E#58D / Manhand 110 - 2010
This is a board recording of Sunburned with Paul Flaherty, sax GIANT from Connecticut, from the now long-gone, Eagle's Nest, in downtown Northampton, Massachusetts. Its a really weird recording because the only things going through the massive, All-Peavy PA was the sax, the vocals and some electronics. The rest of the band sound is just bleed onto the 2 live mics on stage. Terry the Sound Engineer, took the liberty to add weirdo board effects to Paul's sax and thats also him giving the last call announcements.
This is my personal all-time favorite Sunburned record (JM). Its totally fried. Download includes info insert and liner notes by Matt Krefting.
Originally released as a cassette on Thurston Moore's Ecstatic Peace and then in a vinyl numbered edition of 200 on Sunburned's own Manhand label.

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Voizes & Ragui
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
Sounds created, engineered & mixed by Gary War & Robert Thomas
Additional Electronics - Kris Thompson
Additional Vocals on Ragui - Clementine & Valentine Nixon
Cover Art - Gary Panter
Design & Screen Printing by Kristin Anderson
Mastering by Keith Fullerton Whitman
"The sound on Voices is more organic, more entangled with stellar root frequencies than purely spatial ones. The way some of the harsher backwards portions of the material blend with blissed-out voice clouds produces a sensation of otherness as slippery as an eel. That the eel is glowing neon and trapped inside a bubble of lava-gas makes no nevermind.
Heard as a whole, Voizes & Ragui floats into a place that no one expected to exist when it did, and which swiftly ceased to exist once it was done. A unique plateau, balanced between the unexplainable and purely enjoyable, which challenges as it accepts, puts off as it embraces, and wraps its weird tendrils around your brain’s pleasure fronds as though it’s the best friend you ever had." - Byron Coley

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Vulgarisms
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
Sunburned - Vulgarisms (formerly known as Blues for Big Dave and briefly known as Tax Bracket) - Blueberry Honey 93 / MH178.
We were lucky to be able to play outside in the yard during the lockdown in 2020. We played a lot. We recorded everything. We took the winter off and shifted to the TV shows hosted by Shannon. Now we're able to play again outside and just this last week we started playing inside and started overdubbing.
Here's the first result and we hope you like it. This is the first "new" sunburned in a long time...This is the sound of opening the mindcrypt from the inside. We're gearing up to record a new record or 2 at the end of May. We're all ok and feeling optimistic. We also can't thank you, the community of fans, friends and supporters for tuning into what we do month after month. We are grateful. Thank you...
Music played by:
Conrad Capistran
Gary War
Jeremy Pisani
John Moloney
Robert Thomas
Ronald Schneiderman
Sarah Gibbons
Shannon Ketch
Taylor Richardson
Special Guest: Margot Church
Recorded by Moloney / Sequence and artwork by Ron.
The basics were recorded in 2020, overdubs recorded May 6 & 7, 2021.

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Wedlock
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
Sunburned Hand of the Man - Wedlock
Eclipse Records ECL-046 / Sunburned Records (Manhand) 16 & 17. Released in 2005 as a double LP in a one-time edition of 1000 copies.
Recorded straight to a Sony Mini-DV camera. Procession is a sound collage by Robert Thomas.
Sounds by, Agent Z, Agent W, David Bohill, Chris Corsano,Chad Cooper, Critter, Phil Frankliin, Paul Labrecque, John Moloney, Marc Orleans, Rich Pontius, Rob Thomas, Ron Schneiderman, Christine Steele, Valerie Webb and others...Released by Ed Hardy at Eclipse Records. Most, if not all, of the Polaroid Land-Camera Photos were taken by Marc Orleans. Other photos were taken by other members, unfortunately there are no credits on the record. The art was laid out by Rich Pontius. Most of the drums later in the Lp are played by a couple of 4 year olds..
From Mathieu Duval's "My Record Collection" website:
"This double LP is the result of a stay in Alaska during the wedding of a close friend of the group. They performed at the ceremony and these are the recordings from those sessions. Does it sound romantic? Has the Sunburned clan conformed and created what would have been considered appropriate wedding music? Of course not! Does it sound exotic and adventurous? You betcha! Perfect music for a young modern couple and with the Alaskan landscape in the background, I could only imagine how incredible this must have been. By itself, the music sounds like pretty standard SHOTM, with none of the excessive weirdness of the later records. They do sound quite untamed and wild however while performing their own brand of exploratory psych jams. The sound is quite raw and lo-fi, giving it that extra earthy feel. A beautiful wedding gift from these artists that we can all share."
-7.5 rating on Pitchfork
- "one of the best double albums of all time" - Edwin Pouncey - Wire Magazine
Dusted review:
"By my count, this double LP is the fifth Sunburned clan project to drop in 2005, a year in which the band has been mining consistently fresh and often rewarding musical territory. The CD-Rs Manhunt in D and Zample, as well as the Bastet release No Magic Man, sport tighter funkier Krautrock grooves and a new interest in chopped and looped sample excursions and pure electronic experimentation. Wedlock was actually recorded in June 2003, during the Alaskan wedding of members Paul Labrecque and Valerie Webb. In hindsight, it becomes a prequel, transitioning away from the more chest-rattlingly chaotic tribal squall of earlier efforts, serving as the missing link to the group's newly emerging aesthetic.
The opening Procession cuts up snippets of pre-wedding festivities and is as bold a recorded statement as the group has ever made. Little bits of Beethoven piano sonatas, slide guitar riffs and jovial conversation vie for prominence in a collage that's somehow never too busy. Procession segues cinematically into Tent City Roller, which sounds, in comparison, more like one of the beat-driven long-form freakouts beloved of SHOTM fans. All the jingle-jangle rhythms and rattles are present, and so are the customary delay-drenched vocal rants, but the whole thing is subservient to a loping hypnofunk beat that gradually morphs into a grinding Krautgroove more reminiscent of early Can than of 2003 Sunburned. Sure, other tracks on the album bring back the largely acoustic and polyrhythmic noise-wall so commonly associated with this group. Salmon Sez, being a noteworthy example but the epic title track is another fauret into the uhr-groove. After an electronically tinged industrial opening section, the 1970s kick in with a vengeance; the drums are way in the pocket, the heavily phased guitar and minimally riffing bass are infectious and fun.
In fact, fun abounds throughout Wedlock, due in large part to the fact that everybody sounds like they're having a hell of a time. Energy and excitement levels are obviously high, and every one of the seven tracks here is shot through with snippets of conversation, laughter and excesses of celebration. The best man's speech ends the last side on an abstractly humorous and touching note, just before somebody (Val?) says Alright, let's do this cake thing. It's a fittingly spontaneous conclusion to a neat piece of real-life performance art. "

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Weekend at Burnie's
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's "My Record Collection" website:
"Understandably expecting more of the same mind-fuckery found on the Weekend At Burnie's 2 LP, I was pleasantly surprised to hear this short 7" outing was much tighter than it's sister release. The whole A-side's is filled with the amazing Smokescreen, a slow jam driven by a funky bassline, irritating background feedback and the occasional burst of Tourette syndrome inspired poetry. If this would have been the only song on the 7", I would still recommend it, but fear not, there's plenty more goodies. The B-side holds mostly short little sound snippets which are either bizarre jam excerpts or Zample-like sound atrocities. No matter how fucked up though (and believe me, some songs will drag you down into Sunburned's creepy schizophrenic world), there's still a nice flow to these tracks which I couldn't find on the LP. No clue how limited this is and for some reason, the Manhand catalog number is the same as their Civil Complaint cassette!"

Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's "My Record Collection":
"In a deep, flashy Monster Truck Commercial voice complete with fake arena reverb* FIRST there was the mega-madness of Manhunt In D *SWOOSH!!!*, THEN even the GODS trembled before Zample 1, 2, 3 & 4 *THUNDER CRACKS*, but NOW ladies and gentlemen something far more primitive has come our way and threatens to go be-YOND all these freaks of nature *AUDIENCE GASPS!*; something so shockingly unstable even the government wants to pass a law in order to PREVENT this potentially hazardous and frightening recording to find it's way into our streeeeetsahHHH! *GASPS FOR AIR with delay effects*. *TRUMPETS TOOT!* So lock in your kids and warn the neighbors: Weekend At Burnie's 2 is the Sunburned ones' most fucked up album in ages! From the heavy metal buzzsaw of Leather Diaper to the symphony of inmates that is the title track, prepare to be SUNBURNED! sunburned! sunburned! sunburned!"

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: When The Shit Hits The Jazz
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
'Holy psychedelic miasma! I can imagine the red lights of the den, the smoke, the furry orange carpets and the palliette. I can see the people dancing, their bodies contorted because of the wiggly sounds, like a hundred hungry worms reaching for the morning sun. Everything is in a fish eye perspective. You're not sure if that girl with the bandana is actually two feet away or at the other side of the room. You reach out to her (she's pretty), but you hit dead air. Besides, the sight of your hand waving is far more interesting. People are talking. You wonder if it's about you for a second, maybe they're teasing? Nah, it's them... it's just them. You're your own person. You see through their scheme and congratulate yourself. Fuzzy voices, Satan, he speaks to you at times, or maybe a cat in heat, regardless it's all heart shapes and triangles. No fret. No fret man! The shit just hit the jazz and it's fucking sweet!'

A Sunburned Classic.
Featuring – Brian Donnely, Cooper, Capistran, Cousin Rich, Critter, Bohill, Moloney, Orleans, Franklin, Pontius, R Thomas
Recorded live in Massachusetts. 2000-2001. Some of this material comes from the Stone For... Concert on Amherst Common and the rest probably comes from the Sunburned loft in Charlestown, Massachusetts.
Lettering by Joshua Burkett. Drawing by Chad Cooper. Album editing by Rob Thomas.
From Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
Almost as potent as Jaybird, Wildanimal boasts forth Sunburned Hand Of The Man's ability to really stretch your mind like putty until you are able to perceive the sounds they create. There are some eastern influences on the first track, with raga-esque fake sitar sounds and throat singing (behind a wall of reverb of course). These guys must take some really crazy shit to make this stuff. Some of these songs remind me of the very obscure japanese group Brast Burn because of the repetitive motifs and mantra-like chanting. It's as psychedelic as ever, but not quite as intense as it's predecessor. It definitely put you in relaxed mode. Close your eyes, let yourself go and enjoy the ride; it'll be quite colorful!

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Zample Volume 1
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
'Geez! Sometimes the Sunburned clan can come out with something that's so completely out of left field that it'll break your legs and force you to the ground, weeping. What the fuck is this album? The first track, Read My Mind is basically scraping percussive instruments accompanied by someone chanting "Ooga-booga" over and over again (!!?). The rest sounds like pagan devil-worshipping music. This is by far, their craziest effort yet, even more so than A Manhunt In D. The arrangements are quite skeletal, almost nonexistent with a few strange noises to liven things up a bit once in a while. On Thin Air, you get a false upbeat dance music start before immediately evaporating into the ether. The very next track could have been a song on Pee Wee's Playhouse. Can't say I really enjoy this album much. I like strange music, but without at least a semblance of dynamics, my attention is lost.
Sunburned Hand of the Man.credits:
released May 5, 2005
Zample Volume 1 - Manhand 21 - 2005
The First in the Zample Series showcasing some of the weirdest Sunburned Loft recordings. Artwork by Robert Thomas.

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Zample Volume 2
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
From Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
'Zample Volume One was one crazy fucking album which was really a showcase for Sunburned Hand Of The Man's most bizarre, unadulterated, auto-destructive sound explorations. This second volume continues along the same line, with thirty-one new exercises of the most unwholesome kind. Contrary to the first volume however, these new pieces often have a certain drive which prevents them from crumbling to pieces and yes, some of these miniatures actually include a certain groove. The progression between songs feels very haphazard: some tracks sound like they are actually just a part of a longer track with a chapter cut placed for no apparent reason (Toucher) while other numbers cut to the next one just as one gets into the song's groove. All of this mess is of course crammed into an extremely lo-fi package. The insert lists this album as Manhand044 (A Taste Of Never), Manhand046 is correct according to the group's online discography.'

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Zample Volume 3
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
from Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
Yet another excursion into the sunburned clan's more alienating sounds, Zample Volume Three continues the series in a slightly more elegant manner. With only twelve tracks this time (compared to 31 and 23 on volumes 2 and 4 respectively), the collective have enough time to extend most of these jams into something slightly more cohesive than before (only the last few tracks are short bursts of complete barnyard weirdness). Don't be fooled however, this doesn't mean that any of these tracks make any sense, in fact, they're as fucked up as ever, but they are also relatively easier to approach. What's more, this third volume in the series beats the whole Sunburned discography put together when it comes to lo-fi sound quality. I've never heard so much hiss on an album this side of Loren Connors, it sometimes even becomes overwhelming if you lose track of the music behind it. Well worth it if you can get past the sound.'
Sunburned Hand of the Man.credits:
released June 1, 2007

Artwork and package by Robert Thomas, insert by John Moloney. this was only released ad a very limited tour cdr.

Sunburned Hand of the Man.title: Zample Volume 4
Sunburned Hand of the Man.about:
from Mathieu Duval's 'My Record Collection' website:
'Zample 4 could be considered a sister album to the third volume in the Zample series. Both were released simultaneously and, besides the number of tracks (which is almost doubled here), both are incredibly lo-fi and filled with completely mind-boggling jams and bizarre fillers that fans will either love or hate. The Zample series have always been a showcase of the group at their most chaotic, the members are renowned for being able to channel their thoughts and make sense out of extremely fucked up musical situations and this comes through at times even on this album, but the music here is often so repetitive or muddled that one couldn't be blamed for dismissing this album as simply leftover bits and pieces from longer jams (which it most probably is). It's all hit-or-miss, with some moments of pure brilliance hidden within the muck. Give it a few listens and soon enough you'll find the diamonds in the rough. Limited as always.'
